qas.question: Which European emperor painted their palace red?
In what year did cardinals in the Roman Catholic church start wearing red?
When was Saint Denis Basilica rebuilt?
Who rebuilt the basilica of Saint Denis?
Christ and which other Christian figure were often painted red in medieval painting?
Who wore red shoes as a symbol of authority?

plausible_answers.text: Roman Catholic cardinals began to wear red costumes

qas.question: What did Suger Abbe add to the Saint Denis Basilica?

context: Red was the color of the banner of the Byzantine emperors. In Western Europe, <a0_0><b5_0>Emperor Charlemagne<b5_0/><a0_0/> painted his palace red as a very visible symbol of his authority, and wore red shoes at his coronation. Kings, princes and, beginning in <a1_0>1295<a1_0/>, <b6_0>Roman Catholic cardinals began to wear red costumes<b6_0/>. When <a3_0>Abbe Suger<a3_0/> rebuilt <b7_0>Saint Denis Basilica<b7_0/> outside Paris in the early <a2_0>12th century<a2_0/>, he added <b8_0>stained glass windows<b8_0/> colored blue cobalt glass and red glass tinted with copper. Together they flooded the basilica with a mystical light. Soon stained glass windows were being added to cathedrals all across France, England and Germany. In Medieval painting red was used to attract attention to the most important figures; both Christ and the <a4_0>Virgin Mary<a4_0/> were commonly painted wearing red mantles.
